Comment: As much as I shit on the DNC for being reactionary centrist hacks, this is actually a good move.  Post New Deal Democrats (from 76-present) neglected state legislature so badly. It allowed the gerrymandering to get worse and worse and this is the first of many steps to turning that page.  Democrats used to dominate state legislature. There's currently about 4,100 Republicans in state legislative seats to about 3,200 Democrats. Chip away in the state houses for the long term projects.  The GOP motivates their base across consistent ideological points with local flavor sprinkled on top. Democrats need to recapture the message that local government affects people the most, focus on statehouses and start peeling back control from the GOP.
Author: Pike_Gordon

Author: MajorAstronaut7970

Comment: Agreed. The Democrats are facing a monumental task to undo 50 years of listlessness.  I read a good book last week called Chaotic Neutral by Ed Burmilla, an unabashed progressive, but talented political historian tracing the shift of the party from being a stalwart for the working class to being the baroque lifestyle branding it's become.  A large portion is focused on how Democrats dominated statehouses into the 90s and how the gerrymandering of 2000 and 2010 from state legislature slimmed down Democratic national chances to gain consistent majorities.  He also goes into the way that the Republican party is able to consistently message their party platform at the localest of local levels (think about insane school board members) all the way to the white house. And how Democrats haven't responded to this shift for 20 years and it detached people from the national party. I don't agree with all his points necessarily but overall I highly recommend it.
Author: Pike_Gordon

Comment: And that was at a time when there were tons of actual swing voters and split ticket voters. Bush also tried to privatize Social Security in 2005 and got huge backlash for it and the unpopularity of the Iraq Invasion had come to light. It was a perfect storm of everything, none of which the Democrats actually did. The cherry on top of course was the most well spoken, articulate, and charismatic candidate fell right into the Democrats lap when Obama decided to run for President earlier than expected and shot up the primary polls seemingly out of nowhere to snag the nomination.
